And it's really the podcast changed a lot since we started this thing, because at the beginning, we had quite long episodes with many parts.
So we had group discussions, we had interviews with people, and then we even had a few monologues.
I remember Havi Kravitz doing a few kind of statements where he explained his opinion on certain things.
It was a bit more like maybe a traditional radio show.
It wasn't bad.
I think it worked in some ways, but I think we realized over time that it made sense to try and separate these different genres.
So we switched to more either one-on-one interviews that lasted the whole episode, so about half an hour, and then separate group discussions about whatever was going on in the diamond world.
And also another thing I noticed that has changed since December 2017 is that we're not alone anymore.
At the time when we launched, there was maybe one other diamond or jewelry podcast, but now there's quite a few.
JCK has got one, the Plum Club has got one, Paul Zinniski, analyst has got one, and our very own Avi Kravitz has also got his own one.
So it's really taken off this idea.
Sonja, what do you feel has changed about the, let's start with our podcast.
What do you feel has changed over the years?
I feel like, you know, people wanted to explore the new medium.
It was in a first, John Costello was the publisher at the time, was really into podcasts.
He used to go every day at lunchtime, working for an hour, listening to podcasts.
He was a huge consumer and we were not, you know, there were tons of podcasts already.
We invented podcasts in any possible way in 2017.
It was already a thriving scene when we started, but being the diamond industry, the diamond industry not being so much digital, so much on social media.
So our podcast was the first and I think people just saw it's such a really nice, direct way to engage with your audience.
People are on the go, people listen to things on their commute.
It felt like the format was right.
You don't need so much production.
We're very lucky we have a producer on this podcast, but we know at the moment,  for example, we're all recording from home, you know, we don't go to a studio anymore.
So I think for a lot of people, you know, you could interview anyone you wanted in the world just with your laptop, your application, and you could then distribute it to the world.
So I can see the appeal of a podcast for a lot of people.
And I think a voice and people are always looking for authenticity.
They're looking for a personal voice.
So, you know, when you mentioned Paul's podcast or Avi's new podcast, our podcast as well, I think people interact with us as personalities in different ways.
ways than just reading an article with a byline that sometimes gets missed because it's a news item and you just read a lot.

I agree.

But I feel like, you know, since 2017, a lot more people are using social media, maximizing the potential.

They are great, you know, if each individual has more opportunities, that also speaks to the jewelry market and the diamond dealers.

to be episode number 80, which is selling diamonds on Instagram.

your father is not this diamond teller everyone knows for years and has been doing business with.

But I think that since he got caught, he has been working to do a lot of good and he actually  for free with a lot of the FBI and different police and he helps to impart knowledge of how he committed the crimes, the types of things that he's looking for and that other people like him would be looking for and tries to help jurors make their stores more robbery proof.
So I found it actually heartwarming that he's turned his life around in that way and that he's trying to correct the wrongs that he committed.

keywords: actual first stable color treatment ever done

sentence: And even though it's the first treatment, which means it's known since about 1910, 1915, we're still having huge problems identifying the irradiation because naturally irradiated diamonds basically get their color from the same effect as artificially irradiated diamonds.
So it causes an enormous headache to labs since a long time.
Today's status is unfortunately that there are very few labs that even dare to give an origin on such stones.
So normally when you submit a green diamond to any lab except a few, you will get undetermined.
They just don't dare to even claim that a stone might be natural or not.

The unfortunate situation that the market is in at the moment is that a lot or let's say quite a bit of stones that have been certified as natural are not too far away past, have been recently  certified by the same lab in recent years and came back as not natural anymore.

You know, they basically changed from a natural origin to undetermined or even treated, which has created quite a bit of unhappiness in the market, as you may imagine, because some of the stones involved are really high dollar.
Right.
When you say they were originally graded in the not too recent past, how long ago would that be typically?
Stones that have been sent back in the 20s, the 2020s to 2023s came back as they were originally natural color and then came back as undetermined or even treated.
And they were routinely sent to a lab for another check.
Yeah, just to send it back as an upgrade.
That's what often is required if you have a stone out of stock for a long time and people require an upgrade certificate.
It's like a standard thing, but I mean the unhappy situation that you're going to get a  It was an interesting interview with him.
I certainly enjoyed it very much.

And it was just at the time actually, when there was a lot of discussion about many issues in grading going on in the market about digital certificates and then also about whether it was possible to use technology to trace diamonds through the supply chain.
